{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3117625,"name":"Chris","username":"Chris2fourlaw","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/3da27b/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-07T06:03:34.107Z","cooked":"

Hello fellow programmers and FIRST robotics team members!

I am excited to announce the release of ntcore-ts-client: a TypeScript library for communication over WPILib’s NetworkTables 4.0 protocol. It offers a variety of features, including:

  • Togglable auto-reconnect
  • Callbacks for new data on subscriptions
  • Callbacks for connection listeners
  • Retrying for messages queued during a connection loss
  • On-the-fly server switching with resubscribing and republishing
  • Generic types for Topics
  • Client-side data validation using Zod
  • Close to server-matching timestamping using RTT calculation

One of the key benefits of this library is the ability to use it as a data source for a web-based robot dashboard. Web dashboards offer customizable and easy-to-create solutions for displaying real-time data from a robot, which can provide a competitive advantage through improved understanding of the robot’s performance and status during a competition. This can be helpful for both drivers and pit crew to have a clear understanding of the robot’s performance and status during a competition.

Additionally, ntcore-ts-client can run natively in the browser, so there is no need for an extra client-side runtime such as pynetworktables2js. It is also typesafe, using generics to ensure that data is handled correctly, and it includes client-side data validation using the Zod library.

I welcome contributions to this project and am looking for help with making the software more stable and improving its functionality.

For more information on how to use this library, including installation instructions and examples check out the project’s GitHub page.

More detailed API documentation is available at: https://ntcore.chrislawson.dev

Team 973 will be using this library as our NetworkTables client, but it is important to note that this is an individual project maintained by myself and is otherwise not affiliated with the team.

Thank you for your interest in this project. I hope it will be a valuable tool for this season!

Hi all,

Quick announcement that running directly in NodeJS is now supported!

The full release notes for this new version (v0.1.0-beta.0) is available on the GitHub Release page.

Hey again,

Version 0.2.0 has been released: Release 0.2.0 · Chris2fourlaw/ntcore-ts-client · GitHub

Thank you for all the support, feature requests, and for notifying me of bugs. Based on the usage and feedback, I’ve decided to mark this release as production.

As always, feel free to open an issue or PR for future bug finds or feature requests.

Summary of changes

Breaking Changes

  • BREAKING CHANGE: deprecated NetworkTables.createInstance*()
    • Please use NetworkTables.getInstanceByTeam() and NetworkTables.getInstanceByURI()
  • BREAKING CHANGE: removed NetworkTables.getInstance() and NetworkTables.getServerURL()
  • BREAKING CHANGE: deprecated NetworkTableTypeInfos
    • Fixed typo: now called NetworkTablesTypeInfos (NetworkTables plural! With S!)

New Features

  • feat: allow multiple connections

Bug fixes

  • fix: rename NetworkTableTypeInfos to NetworkTablesTypeInfos
  • fix: connect to the correct mDNS address
    • We were trying to connect to roborio-frc-<team>.local instead of roborio-<team>-frc.local
  • fix: bug with creating instance on same URI w/ different port
  • fix: queue value to published topic w/o server connection

Misc commits

  • chore: bump version
  • chore: update deps
  • style: prepend nt client id with ntcore-ts-
  • chore: update deps
  • chore: bump version to 0.2.0

Another cool thing

I want to thank @Cr1spyBacon8r for creating a React library for this client!: GitHub - CrispyBacon1999/ntcore-react: Quickly connect your React App to NetworkTables

This will greatly help teams who want to onboard to this industry-standard web framework.
